name.text: Reaction Forces and Free Body Diagram . Level 4.Question ID #1

questiontext.text:
A simply supported beam of length 78 cm is shown in the figure above. There are two supports, one at either end of the beam, hence reactions forces R1 and R2. There are 2 uniformly distributed loads (UDLs) as shown. All distances are measured relative to A.

By resolving forces and taking moments, determine the value of reaction forces, R1 and R2.

You may assume a value of g of 10 m/s2.

Give your answer to 2 d.p.

R1: {1:NUMERICAL:=34.49:0.3449#Good job!!~*#Incorrect}N
R2: {1:NUMERICAL:=15.51:0.1551#Good job!!~*#Incorrect}N

generalfeedback.text:
For the purposes of calculating reaction forces and moments, one can use the Equivalent Free Body Diagram, where a uniformly distributed load (UDL) is considered to be a point load at its centre of mass, as per the image below:

For each UDL in turn, calculate the load value and position (as per the previous question).

When a system is in equilibrium the total forces and the total moment need to be equal to zero; otherwise the system will be moving or rotating, respectively.

Use the convention that upward forces and anti-clockwise moments are positive, as shown in the diagram below.

In this case taking moments about A, we have:

$$\small\sum$$ Mz=0 $$\rightarrow$$ (0.78m x R2) - (0.17m x 40N) - (0.53m x 10N) = 0

Hence:

R2 = 15.51N.


In this case resolving vertical forces, we have:

$$\small\sum$$ Fy=0 $$\rightarrow$$ R1 + R2 - 40 - 10 = 0.

Hence:

R1 = 34.49N.


The equation $$\small\sum$$ Fx=0 still holds true in this case, but is not used here as there are no forces with an x-component.

hint.text:
HINT

For a system to be in equilibirum, total forces in both x and y directions must be balanced.

Also, for a system to be in equilibrium, the sum of the clockwise moments must be equal to the sum of the anticlockwise moments.

For the purposes of calculating reaction forces and moments, a uniformly distributed load (UDL) can be considered to be a point load at its centre of mass, when constructing an Equivalent Free Body Diagram.

Don't forget to consider both UDLs in this case.

questiontext.text:
A simply supported beam of length 161 cm is shown in the figure above. There are two supports, one at either end of the beam, hence reactions forces R1 and R2. There are 2 uniformly distributed loads (UDLs) as shown. All distances are measured relative to A.

By resolving forces and taking moments, determine the value of reaction forces, R1 and R2.

You may assume a value of g of 10 m/s2.

Give your answer to 2 d.p.

R1: {1:NUMERICAL:=33.35:0.3335#Good job!!~*#Incorrect}N
R2: {1:NUMERICAL:=36.65:0.3665#Good job!!~*#Incorrect}N

generalfeedback.text:
For the purposes of calculating reaction forces and moments, one can use the Equivalent Free Body Diagram, where a uniformly distributed load (UDL) is considered to be a point load at its centre of mass, as per the image below:

For each UDL in turn, calculate the load value and position (as per the previous question).

When a system is in equilibrium the total forces and the total moment need to be equal to zero; otherwise the system will be moving or rotating, respectively.

Use the convention that upward forces and anti-clockwise moments are positive, as shown in the diagram below.

In this case taking moments about A, we have:

$$\small\sum$$ Mz=0 $$\rightarrow$$ (1.61m x R2) - (0.4m x 30N) - (1.175m x 40N) = 0

Hence:

R2 = 36.65N.


In this case resolving vertical forces, we have:

$$\small\sum$$ Fy=0 $$\rightarrow$$ R1 + R2 - 30 - 40 = 0.

Hence:

R1 = 33.35N.


The equation $$\small\sum$$ Fx=0 still holds true in this case, but is not used here as there are no forces with an x-component.

hint.text:
HINT

For a system to be in equilibirum, total forces in both x and y directions must be balanced.

Also, for a system to be in equilibrium, the sum of the clockwise moments must be equal to the sum of the anticlockwise moments.

For the purposes of calculating reaction forces and moments, a uniformly distributed load (UDL) can be considered to be a point load at its centre of mass, when constructing an Equivalent Free Body Diagram.

Don't forget to consider both UDLs in this case.

name.text: Reaction Forces and Free Body Diagram . Level 4.Question ID #27

questiontext.text:
A simply supported beam of length 44 cm is shown in the figure above. There are two supports, one at either end of the beam, hence reactions forces R1 and R2. There are 2 uniformly distributed loads (UDLs) as shown. All distances are measured relative to A.

By resolving forces and taking moments, determine the value of reaction forces, R1 and R2.

You may assume a value of g of 10 m/s2.

Give your answer to 2 d.p.

R1: {1:NUMERICAL:=90.68:0.9068#Good job!!~*#Incorrect}N
R2: {1:NUMERICAL:=69.32:0.6932#Good job!!~*#Incorrect}N

generalfeedback.text:
For the purposes of calculating reaction forces and moments, one can use the Equivalent Free Body Diagram, where a uniformly distributed load (UDL) is considered to be a point load at its centre of mass, as per the image below:

For each UDL in turn, calculate the load value and position (as per the previous question).

When a system is in equilibrium the total forces and the total moment need to be equal to zero; otherwise the system will be moving or rotating, respectively.

Use the convention that upward forces and anti-clockwise moments are positive, as shown in the diagram below.

In this case taking moments about A, we have:

$$\small\sum$$ Mz=0 $$\rightarrow$$ (0.44m x R2) - (0.11m x 100N) - (0.325m x 60N) = 0

Hence:

R2 = 69.32N.


In this case resolving vertical forces, we have:

$$\small\sum$$ Fy=0 $$\rightarrow$$ R1 + R2 - 100 - 60 = 0.

Hence:

R1 = 90.68N.


The equation $$\small\sum$$ Fx=0 still holds true in this case, but is not used here as there are no forces with an x-component.

hint.text:
HINT

For a system to be in equilibirum, total forces in both x and y directions must be balanced.

Also, for a system to be in equilibrium, the sum of the clockwise moments must be equal to the sum of the anticlockwise moments.

For the purposes of calculating reaction forces and moments, a uniformly distributed load (UDL) can be considered to be a point load at its centre of mass, when constructing an Equivalent Free Body Diagram.

Don't forget to consider both UDLs in this case.

Also, for a system to be in equilibrium, the sum of the clockwise moments must be equal to the sum of the anticlockwise moments.

For the purposes of calculating reaction forces and moments, a uniformly distributed load (UDL) can be considered to be a point load at its centre of mass, when constructing an Equivalent Free Body Diagram.

Don't forget to consider both UDLs in this case.

name.text: Reaction Forces and Free Body Diagram . Level 4.Question ID #40

questiontext.text:
A simply supported beam of length 144 cm is shown in the figure above. There are two supports, one at either end of the beam, hence reactions forces R1 and R2. There are 2 uniformly distributed loads (UDLs) as shown. All distances are measured relative to A.

By resolving forces and taking moments, determine the value of reaction forces, R1 and R2.

You may assume a value of g of 10 m/s2.

Give your answer to 2 d.p.

R1: {1:NUMERICAL:=60.38:0.6038#Good job!!~*#Incorrect}N
R2: {1:NUMERICAL:=79.62:0.7962#Good job!!~*#Incorrect}N

generalfeedback.text:
For the purposes of calculating reaction forces and moments, one can use the Equivalent Free Body Diagram, where a uniformly distributed load (UDL) is considered to be a point load at its centre of mass, as per the image below:

For each UDL in turn, calculate the load value and position (as per the previous question).

When a system is in equilibrium the total forces and the total moment need to be equal to zero; otherwise the system will be moving or rotating, respectively.

Use the convention that upward forces and anti-clockwise moments are positive, as shown in the diagram below.

In this case taking moments about A, we have:

$$\small\sum$$ Mz=0 $$\rightarrow$$ (1.44m x R2) - (0.32m x 30N) - (0.955m x 110N) = 0

Hence:

R2 = 79.62N.


In this case resolving vertical forces, we have:

$$\small\sum$$ Fy=0 $$\rightarrow$$ R1 + R2 - 30 - 110 = 0.

Hence:

R1 = 60.38N.


The equation $$\small\sum$$ Fx=0 still holds true in this case, but is not used here as there are no forces with an x-component.

hint.text:
HINT

For a system to be in equilibirum, total forces in both x and y directions must be balanced.

Also, for a system to be in equilibrium, the sum of the clockwise moments must be equal to the sum of the anticlockwise moments.

For the purposes of calculating reaction forces and moments, a uniformly distributed load (UDL) can be considered to be a point load at its centre of mass, when constructing an Equivalent Free Body Diagram.

Don't forget to consider both UDLs in this case.

For a system to be in equilibirum, total forces in both x and y directions must be balanced.

Also, for a system to be in equilibrium, the sum of the clockwise moments must be equal to the sum of the anticlockwise moments.

For the purposes of calculating reaction forces and moments, a uniformly distributed load (UDL) can be considered to be a point load at its centre of mass, when constructing an Equivalent Free Body Diagram.

Don't forget to consider both UDLs in this case.

name.text: Reaction Forces and Free Body Diagram . Level 4.Question ID #53

questiontext.text:
A simply supported beam of length 42 cm is shown in the figure above. There are two supports, one at either end of the beam, hence reactions forces R1 and R2. There are 2 uniformly distributed loads (UDLs) as shown. All distances are measured relative to A.

By resolving forces and taking moments, determine the value of reaction forces, R1 and R2.

You may assume a value of g of 10 m/s2.

Give your answer to 2 d.p.

R1: {1:NUMERICAL:=148.69:1.4869#Good job!!~*#Incorrect}N
R2: {1:NUMERICAL:=121.31:1.2131#Good job!!~*#Incorrect}N

generalfeedback.text:
For the purposes of calculating reaction forces and moments, one can use the Equivalent Free Body Diagram, where a uniformly distributed load (UDL) is considered to be a point load at its centre of mass, as per the image below:

For each UDL in turn, calculate the load value and position (as per the previous question).

When a system is in equilibrium the total forces and the total moment need to be equal to zero; otherwise the system will be moving or rotating, respectively.

Use the convention that upward forces and anti-clockwise moments are positive, as shown in the diagram below.

In this case taking moments about A, we have:

$$\small\sum$$ Mz=0 $$\rightarrow$$ (0.42m x R2) - (0.09m x 140N) - (0.295m x 130N) = 0

Hence:

R2 = 121.31N.


In this case resolving vertical forces, we have:

$$\small\sum$$ Fy=0 $$\rightarrow$$ R1 + R2 - 140 - 130 = 0.

Hence:

R1 = 148.69N.


The equation $$\small\sum$$ Fx=0 still holds true in this case, but is not used here as there are no forces with an x-component.

For a system to be in equilibirum, total forces in both x and y directions must be balanced.

Also, for a system to be in equilibrium, the sum of the clockwise moments must be equal to the sum of the anticlockwise moments.

For the purposes of calculating reaction forces and moments, a uniformly distributed load (UDL) can be considered to be a point load at its centre of mass, when constructing an Equivalent Free Body Diagram.

Don't forget to consider both UDLs in this case.

name.text: Reaction Forces and Free Body Diagram . Level 4.Question ID #66

questiontext.text:
A simply supported beam of length 152 cm is shown in the figure above. There are two supports, one at either end of the beam, hence reactions forces R1 and R2. There are 2 uniformly distributed loads (UDLs) as shown. All distances are measured relative to A.

By resolving forces and taking moments, determine the value of reaction forces, R1 and R2.

You may assume a value of g of 10 m/s2.

Give your answer to 2 d.p.

R1: {1:NUMERICAL:=114.21:1.1421#Good job!!~*#Incorrect}N
R2: {1:NUMERICAL:=75.79:0.7579#Good job!!~*#Incorrect}N

generalfeedback.text:
For the purposes of calculating reaction forces and moments, one can use the Equivalent Free Body Diagram, where a uniformly distributed load (UDL) is considered to be a point load at its centre of mass, as per the image below:

For each UDL in turn, calculate the load value and position (as per the previous question).

When a system is in equilibrium the total forces and the total moment need to be equal to zero; otherwise the system will be moving or rotating, respectively.

Use the convention that upward forces and anti-clockwise moments are positive, as shown in the diagram below.

In this case taking moments about A, we have:

$$\small\sum$$ Mz=0 $$\rightarrow$$ (1.52m x R2) - (0.33m x 120N) - (1.08m x 70N) = 0

Hence:

R2 = 75.79N.


In this case resolving vertical forces, we have:

$$\small\sum$$ Fy=0 $$\rightarrow$$ R1 + R2 - 120 - 70 = 0.

Hence:

R1 = 114.21N.


The equation $$\small\sum$$ Fx=0 still holds true in this case, but is not used here as there are no forces with an x-component.

For a system to be in equilibirum, total forces in both x and y directions must be balanced.

Also, for a system to be in equilibrium, the sum of the clockwise moments must be equal to the sum of the anticlockwise moments.

For the purposes of calculating reaction forces and moments, a uniformly distributed load (UDL) can be considered to be a point load at its centre of mass, when constructing an Equivalent Free Body Diagram.

Don't forget to consider both UDLs in this case.

name.text: Reaction Forces and Free Body Diagram . Level 4.Question ID #79

questiontext.text:
A simply supported beam of length 64 cm is shown in the figure above. There are two supports, one at either end of the beam, hence reactions forces R1 and R2. There are 2 uniformly distributed loads (UDLs) as shown. All distances are measured relative to A.

By resolving forces and taking moments, determine the value of reaction forces, R1 and R2.

You may assume a value of g of 10 m/s2.

Give your answer to 2 d.p.

R1: {1:NUMERICAL:=34.53:0.3453#Good job!!~*#Incorrect}N
R2: {1:NUMERICAL:=15.47:0.1547#Good job!!~*#Incorrect}N

generalfeedback.text:
For the purposes of calculating reaction forces and moments, one can use the Equivalent Free Body Diagram, where a uniformly distributed load (UDL) is considered to be a point load at its centre of mass, as per the image below:

For each UDL in turn, calculate the load value and position (as per the previous question).

When a system is in equilibrium the total forces and the total moment need to be equal to zero; otherwise the system will be moving or rotating, respectively.

Use the convention that upward forces and anti-clockwise moments are positive, as shown in the diagram below.

In this case taking moments about A, we have:

$$\small\sum$$ Mz=0 $$\rightarrow$$ (0.64m x R2) - (0.14m x 40N) - (0.43m x 10N) = 0

Hence:

R2 = 15.47N.


In this case resolving vertical forces, we have:

$$\small\sum$$ Fy=0 $$\rightarrow$$ R1 + R2 - 40 - 10 = 0.

Hence:

R1 = 34.53N.


The equation $$\small\sum$$ Fx=0 still holds true in this case, but is not used here as there are no forces with an x-component.

For a system to be in equilibirum, total forces in both x and y directions must be balanced.

Also, for a system to be in equilibrium, the sum of the clockwise moments must be equal to the sum of the anticlockwise moments.

For the purposes of calculating reaction forces and moments, a uniformly distributed load (UDL) can be considered to be a point load at its centre of mass, when constructing an Equivalent Free Body Diagram.

Don't forget to consider both UDLs in this case.

name.text: Reaction Forces and Free Body Diagram . Level 4.Question ID #92

questiontext.text:
A simply supported beam of length 98 cm is shown in the figure above. There are two supports, one at either end of the beam, hence reactions forces R1 and R2. There are 2 uniformly distributed loads (UDLs) as shown. All distances are measured relative to A.

By resolving forces and taking moments, determine the value of reaction forces, R1 and R2.

You may assume a value of g of 10 m/s2.

Give your answer to 2 d.p.

R1: {1:NUMERICAL:=87.24:0.8724#Good job!!~*#Incorrect}N
R2: {1:NUMERICAL:=112.76:1.1276#Good job!!~*#Incorrect}N

generalfeedback.text:
For the purposes of calculating reaction forces and moments, one can use the Equivalent Free Body Diagram, where a uniformly distributed load (UDL) is considered to be a point load at its centre of mass, as per the image below:

For each UDL in turn, calculate the load value and position (as per the previous question).

When a system is in equilibrium the total forces and the total moment need to be equal to zero; otherwise the system will be moving or rotating, respectively.

Use the convention that upward forces and anti-clockwise moments are positive, as shown in the diagram below.

In this case taking moments about A, we have:

$$\small\sum$$ Mz=0 $$\rightarrow$$ (0.98m x R2) - (0.215m x 50N) - (0.665m x 150N) = 0

Hence:

R2 = 112.76N.


In this case resolving vertical forces, we have:

$$\small\sum$$ Fy=0 $$\rightarrow$$ R1 + R2 - 50 - 150 = 0.

Hence:

R1 = 87.24N.


The equation $$\small\sum$$ Fx=0 still holds true in this case, but is not used here as there are no forces with an x-component.

Don't forget to consider both UDLs in this case.
